I've been thinking about this whole investment think. Somehow, I think the equations are wrong, Here's what I think. You have 1$. You go and buy bread. 1$ = 1 bread. You have 1$. You go and invest. After a day, if everything goes really well, you get 2 $. But 1$ != 2$. So, during that time, something happened to the dollar. What exactly happened? Well, the value of the stocks fluctuated. Because of the fluctuation, the stocks you invested in gained more value. So, the value of the $ you invested represents a function that describes the fluctuation. But since it represents something different than the $ you used to buy bread, it's not correct to use the same sign. You can't use the same notation for something that represents a fluctuation and also something that represent value at a given moment. So, in order for this to make sense, you need to consider that the $ you use to invest is actually d$/dt. A derivative. In the same way acceleration is the derivative of speed.

The main topics of the video are financial markets and the application of mathematics in finance.  The speaker, Jake Shaw, begins by introducing himself and the other instructors for the course. He then asks the students a few questions to get a sense of their backgrounds.  The speaker then tells a story about his first day at Morgan Stanley, when he was asked to find the "vega report." He didn't know what vega was, so he asked his desk quant. The quant told him that vega is a measure of a portfolio's sensitivity to volatility.  The speaker then goes on to discuss some of the basic concepts of financial markets, such as exchanges, products, and currencies. He also talks about how financial markets have changed over time, with the rise of electronic trading platforms and over-the-counter trading.  The speaker then gives an example of how mathematics is used in finance. He asks the students to imagine that they have a stock that is currently trading at $88. The stock has a 20% chance of going up to $100 and an 80% chance of going down to $50. The speaker asks the students whether they would rather sell the stock now or wait until the end of the year.  The speaker then discusses the concept of risk tolerance. He says that the answer to the question of whether to sell the stock now or wait until the end of the year depends on the individual's risk tolerance. Someone who is risk-averse would be more likely to sell the stock now, while someone who is more risk-tolerant would be more likely to wait until the end of the year.  The speaker concludes the video by encouraging the students to learn more about the financial markets and the application of mathematics in finance. He says that the course will cover a wide range of topics, from basic concepts to more advanced applications.

I have to share. Through this pandemic I’ve learned that data isn’t always the end-all, be-all. I’ve learned that my day to day experience provides a fairly good map for the world.
